snippet: Liu Yang was part of a three-person crew expected to complete the country’s first manned docking mission, an important step in an ambitious plan to build a Chinese space station by 2020.
abstract: Liu Yang, China's first female astronaut, is part of a three-person crew expected to complete country’s first manned docking mission, a big step in an ambitious plan to build a space station by 2020; the crew will spend up to 20 days in space and dock with the orbiting Tiangong 1 space lab module, a miniature space station launched in September 2011; the crew will conduct experiments and live for a time in the space module.

byline.original: By DAVID BARBOZA and KEVIN DREW
byline.contributor: David Barboza reported from Shanghai, and Kevin Drew from Hong Kong.

lead_paragraph: Liu Yang was part of a three-person crew expected to complete the country’s first manned docking mission, an important step in an ambitious plan to build a Chinese space station by 2020.

headline.seo: China Sends 3 Astronauts, Including a Woman, Into Space
headline.main: First Female Astronaut From China Blasts Into Space
headline.print_headline: Woman Joins Chinese Crew On Mission To Space Lab
